articles.headline: Pondering a Dire Day: Leaving the Euro
articles.snippet: A growing number of legal and financial experts, to say nothing of the Greeks themselves, are examining in detail what would happen if Greece abandoned the euro.
articles.abstract: A growing number of legal and financial experts, to say nothing of the Greeks themselves, are examining in detail what would happen if Greece abandoned the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It would be Europe’s worst nightmare: after weeks of rumors, the Greek prime minister announces late on a Saturday night that the country will abandon the euro currency and return to the drachma.

articles.headline: Top Earners Not So Lofty in the Days of Recession
articles.snippet: The share of income received by the top 1 percent fell to 17 percent in 2009 from 23 percent in 2007.
articles.abstract: The share of income received by the top 1 percent fell to 17 percent in 2009 from 23 percent in 2007.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hold the condolence cards, but the recession cost the rich.

articles.headline: No Hit Toy to Brighten Retailers’ Christmas
articles.snippet: Without a hot toy, retailers are stocking less, leaning on classic items and possibly discounting less in the final days before Christmas.
articles.abstract: Without a hot toy, retailers are stocking less, leaning on classic items and possibly discounting less in the final days before Christmas.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Christmas less than two weeks away, the toy industry has no runaway hit — leaving many toy shoppers bored and complicating how stores sell holiday inventory.

articles.headline: Rating Agency Warnings Bring Down the Markets
articles.snippet: The market euphoria over last week’s deal by European leaders to shore up the euro currency union succumbed to a darker mood Monday.
articles.abstract: The market euphoria over last week’s deal by European leaders to shore up the euro currency union succumbed to a darker mood Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The market euphoria over last week’s deal by European leaders to shore up the euro currency union succumbed to a darker mood Monday.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Campaign Sends Romney to the Rescue. Ann Romney.
articles.snippet: Ann Romney likes to tell audiences about “the other side of Mitt that you never hear about.”
articles.abstract: Ann Romney likes to tell audiences about “the other side of Mitt that you never hear about.”
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Ann Romney switches off shrill TV coverage of the presidential race “all the time.” She is exasperated by the hyperpartisanship of the moment. As for the debates? “Listen,” she said in a rare interview here, “I don’t even want to go to the debates.”

articles.headline: Premier’s Actions in Iraq Raise U.S. Concerns
articles.snippet: Night raids and mass arrests come as the United States prepares to leave Iraq, leading Western officials to question the country’s course under Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.
articles.abstract: Night raids and mass arrests come as the United States prepares to leave Iraq, leading Western officials to question the country’s course under Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has moved swiftly to consolidate power in advance of the American military withdrawal, offering a glimpse of how Iraq’s post-American identity may take shape, by rounding up hundreds of former Baath Party members and evicting Western companies from the heavily fortified Green Zone.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Tim Arango and Michael S. Schmidt
